intro: Gentiana affinis var. major, commonly known as the greater gentian, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the mountainous regions of Europe and western Asia. It is characterized by its striking blue to violet flowers, which bloom in late summer and early autumn. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with lance-shaped leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in woodland edges or rocky habitats. The flowers are pollinated primarily by bees and other insects, contributing to its role in local ecosystems.
